location.physicalLocation: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: Color photograph of a one story red brick building with a front gable roof. A centrally located entrance portico, supported by two pairs of pillars, covers a concrete porch at the top of four steps leading to a pair of glass doors. Two over two double hung colored glass windows flank the portico and four similar windows are visible on the left side of the building. A low brick ell extends from the left rear and paved asphalt parking places are visible in front and on the left side of the building.
mods.accessCondition: Reproduction permitted for non-profit educational and research purposes only. All reproductions require acknowledgement of the contributing institution. For research inquiries about specific objects, contact the Center for Historic Preservation.

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s history between the end of the American Civil War (1865) and the end of World War II (1945) often gets ignored. Citizenship—what that has meant and how that has changed—is at the heart of this digital exploration into Tennessee history and culture “between the wars." The stories you can explore through the objects, songs, photographs, paintings, and documents of this website are often those of challenges and obstacles placed before those who pursued the rights and benefits of citizenship.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
